unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Violating a Two-Sample $T$ Procedure
question_text:
A hotel manager wishes to compare the number of guests she has per night to the number of guests per night at the other hotel in town.
The manager records the number of guests staying per night during the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at her hotel and compares them to numbers for the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at her competitorâ€™s hotel.
If the manager wishes to perform a two-sample $T$ procedure, what is a potential condition that could be in violation of the $T$ procedure?

choices.text: Sample sizes of $4$ are too small to assume normality.
The data does not come from two independent simple random samples.
In this situation, $np$ and $n (1-p)$ would not be at least $10$, where $n$ is $4$ and $p = 0.5$.
The survey was most likely conducted in a biased manner.
There appear to be no conditions violated.

solution:
Most likely these samples are not independent. On certain days when one hotel is busy, the other hotel is also more likely to be busy. Also, it is quite possible the last $4\text{ weeks}$ are not necessarily representative of the hotel business in this town.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; there are $7\text{ days}$ in a week, so each sample consists of $7\cdot 4 = 28\text{ days}$. Two samples each of size $28$ is large enough to ensure approximate normality for $T$ procedures.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; this condition checks for normality in proportions not means.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; there is nothing in the problem that suggests any bias.
